title: Why should one believe in fate? - Quora

response.answer_text: The abrogation of personal and social responsibility has consumed, both philosophically and theologically, outstanding proportions of attention. Whether we’re speaking of a pure savior martyring himself for the mistakes of others or the hands of the gods invisibly directing the course of human events, the resulting feeling that one is no longer entirely responsible, is the same. Belief is not an avenue to knowledge, so believing in anything does not guarantee any accuracy and of course it has no bearing on what is actually real. Belief, though, like fate offers its own psychological psychological comfort, in this case of avoiding the sense of doubt or ignorance. Too often, the human mind in its quest for absolute certainty takes short cuts through the back alleys of beliefs, only to find neither certainty nor any strong urge to continue searching for truth. So, if you don’t want to know anything or be responsible for anyone, especially yourself, by all means believe in fate. It should be noted that one could philosophically counter the idea of freewill, either completely or by degrees, and still disassemble fate because while freewill questions the autonomy of selfhood based on the context of birth and conditioning, if not on an firmer ontological grounds, fate presumes itself to freely operate without addressing fundamental questions, especially when approached as a belief system.
